@DrSueOosthuizen @AncientTorfaen @ndhags @EnvAgency On the Bassingham side of the river, north of Scotwater bridge this is currently a flooded area, not normally flooded and that makes a lot of sense as the modern embankment normally stops that happening. None of it is pasture now due to modern agriculture
Last week Why was there so much water running down the footpath down to Becks Field #shrewsbury. Is it because @ShrewsSchool built the Hodgson Building?? @envagency – a lot of damage to the footpath

@velohistorian @DrSueOosthuizen @ndhags @EnvAgency Sometimes they were marked as field boundaries. Also, early cartographers were notoriously inaccurate. Interesting about the windmill by the river.
RT @pulse1news: Flood warnings (2nd level on @EnvAgencyYNE scale) have been issued for the River Spen at Cleckheaton and Liversedge, Tyersa…

@terrykinsella Hi Terry, yes. So sad. @Feargal_Sharkey of Undertones and Derry Feis fame is fantastic advocate and fighter for Chalk Rivers. Need to keep pushing @CRTContactUs @EnvAgency to prosecute polluters and clean our rivers up.

@AncientTorfaen @DrSueOosthuizen @ndhags @EnvAgency My suspicion is these water courses were dug post 17th C. I have a copy of the 1678 enclosure map for Carlton le Moorland and they are not marked. Interesting no watermill by the river is marked, but two windmills are. One of which is besides the river
